ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE WEBSITE: Highlights include Japanese Corporate Services Price Index and BoJ Core CPI, Australian NAB Business Confidence and Business Conditions
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

The number of coronavirus cases in China is said to have increased to 2827 and total number of deaths are now at 82. (Guardian)

An antiviral spray against coronavirus has been developed in Shanghai, which can be applied to the throat as a shield from virus. Furthermore, reports added the spray can greatly help protect front-line medical staff although mass-production for public use is not available for now. (People’s Daily)

US CDC confirmed there are still 5 cases of the Coronavirus in the US with no further cases seen and it does not appear to have mutated, while it added that the immediate risk to the US is low at this stage and there is currently no evidence of transmission through imported goods. (Newswires)

US raised China Travel Advisory to Level 3 which urges Americans to reconsider travel and the Canadian government told its citizens to avoid all travel to the Hubei province. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson commented on Huawei in which he stated that we want to have 5G but without compromising national security or the Five Eyes intelligence cooperation. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesman said the EU should not doubt the UK's determination to take back control of UK fishing waters. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said there is no possibility for frictionless trade between the EU and the UK. (Newswires)

ECB’s Mersch (hawkish) said the risks of an asset price correction are rising and current valuations are at high levels, while he added that it is preferable to incorporate financial stability concerns into ECB policy deliberations.

  • German Ifo Business Climate New (Jan) 95.9 vs. Exp. 97 (Prev. 96.3). (Newswires)
  • German Ifo Curr Conditions New (Jan) 99.1 vs. Exp. 99.2 (Prev. 98.8)
  • German Ifo Expectations New (Jan) 92.9 vs. Exp. 95 (Prev. 93.8, Rev. 93.9)

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC President suggested there will be little impact from the Coronavirus on the global oil market for now, according to Algeria state news. (Newswires)

Senior OPEC source stated that deeper production cuts are under prelim discussions as one option to respond to lower prices due to coronavirus, according to FT's Sheppard. (Twitter)

Libya’s NOC Chairman Sanalla said oil production today stood at 262k BPD but could fall to 72k BPD very soon, while he noted some efforts are underway to lift the blockade although the timing is uncertain. (Newswires)

Venezuela is mulling privatizing its oil industry amid its financial struggles, with names touted including Repsol (REP SM), Eni (ENI IM) and Rosneft (ROSN RM), according to sources. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

An Iranian Minister stated it is preparing a new satellite launch site, although the US suggested it is a cover for the development of ballistic missiles. (Newswires)

Taliban spokesman stated that they shot down a plane carrying US military personnel in Ghazni, Afghanistan and noted all on board were killed which included high ranking officers. (Newswires)

 

US

US Senator Romney said it is "increasingly likely" that a minimum of four Republican Senators will be in favour of calling for former National Security Adviser Bolton to testify in the impeachment trial, while reports also noted that a US Republican Senator said former National Security Adviser Bolton's report strengthens the case for witnesses to be called in the Trump impeachment trial. (Newswires)

  • US Dallas Fed Manufacturing Business Index (Jan) -0.2 (Prev. -3.2). (Newswires)
  • US Dallas Fed Manufacturing Output Index 10.5 (Prev. 3.6)
  • US New Home Sales (Dec) 0.694M vs. Exp. 0.73M (Prev. 0.719M, Rev. 0.697M)
  • US New Home Sales (Dec) M/M -0.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. -1.1%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Concerns about the impact of coronavirus on global growth has dictated the tone of trading, seeing stocks negative (largest one day decline in the SPX since October 2nd), bonds bid, oil lower, while the offshore yuan weakened by around 0.8%. The USD and EUR, however, are unmoved. Some desks had suggested equity traders were rotating into names that are more insulated from any potential economic downturn, and sustain earnings in the event the global growth takes a hit; the defensive sectors were the relative outperformers, with utilities, REITs, staples and health care faring best. The pace of Chinese growth could fall by as much as 1ppts, some analysts have argued, and the nation now has a bigger footprint on global growth than it did in 2003 amid the SARS outbreak. Arconic (ARNC) traded higher after its earnings report despite issuing poor guidance and missing top and bottom line estimates. The co. did announce however it expects to reduce its operating costs by USD 300mln on a run rate business and that it will complete its split of its aerospace components and aluminium rolling businesses into two separate entities on April 1st. D.R Horton (DHI) an outperformer in the SPX after top and bottom line beats, as well as providing decent forecasts in Q2 above analyst expectations. AbbVie (ABBV) and Allergan (AGN) traded higher after ABBV announced it is to divest certain drugs in order to approve the merger. SPX -1.60% AT 3243; DOW -1.57% AT 28,535; NDX -2.07% AT 8952.

Yields were lower by around 4-8bps, bull flattening; major curve spreads had narrowed between 1-3bps, with much attention on the 2s5s spread, which went negative again after a lacklustre 2-year auction. Today's price action was a result of the Coronavirus updates, which are beginning to weigh on perceptions of global growth. The US sold 2-year and 5-year notes, the latter tailing by 0.1bps at the lowest yield since August 2017, while the 5-year sale was weak, tailing by 1.1bps. On Tuesday, the US will sell 7-year notes; the current 7-year is trading fair on asset swap against older 7s, SocGen observes, though the bank feels it trades rich on the fly against 5s and 10s. The WI yield is trading above recent stop-out rates, suggesting it trades rich on an outright basis vs previous cycles. With that said, SocGen notes that the last four 7s auctions have been digested well, seeing strong foreign participation, and SocGen thinks that this strong demand may help to offset some of the richness within the sector. The bank has a neutral bias heading into the auction, but notes demand might be affected by Wednesday's FOMC meeting. US T-Note futures settled 19+ ticks higher at 130-28+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 27th January 2020: Coronavirus hits risk appetite as we enter peak earnings season
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 27th January 2020: Coronavirus hits risk appetite as we enter peak earnings season

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Coronavirus deaths and cases rises; German IFO not consistent with ZEW/PMIs; Trump impeachment warrants attention after Bolton revelations. 

* COMING UP: Data & Events: US Durable Goods, Consumer Confidence; US Private Energy Inventories. Speakers: ECB’s Lane; Riksbank’s Ingves & Skingsley; German Finance Minister Scholz & Economy Minister Altmaier. Auctions: US 7-year & 2-year FRN; UK 2029 Gilt; Italy 2023 BTP & 2021 CTZ. Earnings: AAPL, PFE, UTX, LMT, SBUX, MMM, AMD, SYK, EBAY

 

* MARKETS WRAP: Concerns about the impact of coronavirus on global growth has dictated the tone of trading, seeing stocks negative (largest one day decline in the SPX since October 2nd), bonds bid, oil lower, while the offshore yuan weakened by around 0.8%. The USD and EUR, however, are unmoved. Some desks had suggested equity traders were rotating into names that are more insulated from any potential economic downturn, and sustain earnings in the event the global growth takes a hit; the defensive sectors were the relative outperformers, with utilities, REITs, staples and health care faring best. The pace of Chinese growth could fall by as much as 1ppts, some analysts have argued, and the nation now has a bigger footprint on global growth than it did in 2003 amid the SARS outbreak. Meanwhile, the Treasury curve bull-flattened, with much attention on 2s5s, which inverted again. Oil continues to see downside, as does copper. FX was a little more flat (EUR and USD), though gold rose to highs around USD 1586, now eying the psychological USD 1600 mark. Looking forward, earnings season steps up on Tuesday with PFE and UTX before the bell and AAPL and AMD reporting after – by week-end investors will have a more intact gauge of the US corporate sector, with just under 30% of the S&P 500 reporting this week alone.

* CORONAVIRUS: China has extended its Lunar New Year holidays as it continues to try and stop the spread of the coronavirus. New research has shown that the virus can remain dormant for up to two-weeks before symptoms begin showing, raising risks that fresh cases may rise over the next couple of weeks. The US, meanwhile, has raised travel advisories to China, which urges Americans to reconsider travel to the region. The main focus for market participants remains the impact on global growth. China’s main stock exchanges will now resume trading on 3rd February – although that is not necessary the case for business, where the Zhejiang province has reportedly said companies can’t return till February 9th. Desks have become more concerned about its impact on growth; GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt in H1 2020 and may well prompt stimulus measures by the Chinese Government, Danske Bank has argued. (See our full analysis here)

* IMPEACHMENT: Although the market was happy to dismiss it as noise, given that Trump has the support of the GOP controlled Senate, where a two-thirds majority is required to convict the President, weekend news will compel traders to pay more attention. A NY Times article, citing excerpts from former National Securities Advisor Bolton's upcoming book, alleges that Trump wanted to continue freezing funds for security assistance to Ukraine until officials there helped with investigations into Democrats, including Democrat Presidential candidate Joe Biden, which would undermine the central argument put forward by Trump's defence, and will likely increase the pressure on Republican senators to allow witnesses to be called. Trump has already tweeted on the matter, stating he never told Bolton to tie aid to investigations into Democrats, and "in fact, he never complained about this at the time of his very public termination. If John Bolton said this, it was only to sell a book." The WSJ said it was not immediately clear how much the revelations could impact the debate on calling trial witnesses, and it was almost certain not to shift the expectation that Trump won't be convicted, noting that four Republicans would have to join with all Democrats to make that happen. However, a handful of GOP Senators have shown interest in the story, which has the potential to shift the narrative as we head into the Election's Primary Season, which gets underway next week.

* US NEW HOME SALES (DEC): The 694k missed expectations of a rise to 730k (prev. was revised lower to 697k). Essentially, the print was little changed on the month, but the three-month revisions were lower to the tune of 32k, while the supply of new homes rose to 5.7 months’ worth, up from 5.5 months’ previously. Nevertheless, Pantheon Macroeconomics said the trend in new home sales is increasing, tracking the rising trend in mortgage applications. "But sales substantially overshot the pace implied by the mortgage data in four of the five months to November, so the December undershoot looks like a correction," the consultancy said, "we thought that the exceptionally mild weather would keep sales elevated a while longer but we aren’t worried about this dip." Pantheon reminds us that new home sales numbers are wildly erratic, with a margin of error of +/-15% in December, so today’s data is not the final word, and it expects to see new cycle highs over the next few months, and upward pressure on price increases, given very low inventory.

* GERMAN IFO (JAN): The January IFO missed expectations; current conditions New rose a touch to 99.1 (exp. 99.2, prev. 98.8), expectations fell to 92.9 (exp. 95, from a revised – modestly higher - 93.9), while the business climate missed at 95.9 (exp. 97.0, prev. 96.3). "The print breaks with the trend of improving soft data, and highlights differences in the outlook of businesses and financial analysts," Morgan Stanley said; the bank notes that the business climate metric saw registered its first negative print since troughing in August last year, breaking with the trend of steadily improving soft data, with the decrease driven by lower expectations, particularly in the construction and services sectors, while current conditions gained. "The print follows strong increases in surveys of financial analysts, such as the ZEW and Sentix, and highlights differences in the outlook compared to businesses."

* ECB: Mersch (hawkish) said the risks of an asset price correction were rising, and current valuations are at high levels; it is preferable to incorporate financial stability concerns into ECB policy deliberations, he argued. There are good reasons to believe that macro-prudential policy in the Euro area was currently constrained in its effectiveness, Mersch said, there could be a large gap between the HICP and what households perceive to be the increase in their cost of living incorporating owner-occupied housing in the reference rate of inflation for policy would provide a clearer signal for monetary policy to lean against housing price booms.

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 1.05/BBL AT USD 53.14/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLED USD 1.37 LOWER AT USD 59.32/BBL: The energy market’s susceptibility to coronavirus fears extended further on Monday. As the weekend bared news of more deaths in China, and a growing figure of confirmed cases globally, participants further priced in the potential for waning global growth, particularly in China - the largest oil importer. The bearish sentiment saw the crude oil benchmarks gap lower on the futures open, with front month Brent trading below USD 60.00/bbl, before staying rangebound. OPEC officials have said that there would be little impact from the coronavirus on the global oil market, for now, in addition to suggesting the price decline is an exaggeration related to “psychology” and “extreme pessimism”. Citigroup’s analysts note that technical factors could also be exacerbating the sell-off, such as delta hedging as the benchmarks fall through strike prices. Meanwhile, Libya’s NOC announced that oil production on Monday stood at 262k BPD (full capacity is 1.2mln BPD), and that it could fall to 72k BPD very soon, perhaps alleviated some supply glut concerns, which grew last week after it appeared the blockade in place – as implemented by forces loyal to Haftar - could be removed sooner than previously anticipated; NOC also said that some efforts are underway to lift the blockade, although the timing is uncertain. Looking ahead to this week’s energy inventory expectations (bbls): crude +0.5mln, distillates -1.3mln, gasoline +1.2mln and Genscape forecasts Cushing -0.87mln.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLED 19+ TICKS HIGHER AT 130-28+. Yields were lower by around 4-8bps, bull flattening; major curve spreads had narrowed between 1-3bps, with much attention on the 2s5s spread, which went negative again after a lacklustre 2-year auction. Today's price action was a result of the Coronavirus updates, which are beginning to weigh on perceptions of global growth. The US sold 2-year and 5-year notes, the latter tailing by 0.1bps at the lowest yield since August 2017, while the 5-year sale was weak, tailing by 1.1bps. On Tuesday, the US will sell 7-year notes; the current 7-year is trading fair on asset swap against older 7s, SocGen observes, though the bank feels it trades rich on the fly against 5s and 10s. The WI yield is trading above recent stop-out rates, suggesting it trades rich on an outright basis vs previous cycles. With that said, SocGen notes that the last four 7s auctions have been digested well, seeing strong foreign participation, and SocGen thinks that this strong demand may help to offset some of the richness within the sector. The bank has a neutral bias heading into the auction, but notes demand might be affected by Wednesday's FOMC meeting.

* ITALY: BTPs caught a significant bid on Monday, with traders citing reduce risks of snap elections after regional elections over the weekend saw the leftist PD retain the Emilia-Romagna region; there had been fears that right wing parties might would make headway. Indeed, although The League won a majority in Calabria, the votes still represent a setback for The League's efforts to consolidate power, analysts at Stratfor said, although the party remains the country's most popular party on the national level, according to opinion polls, and could win the next general election. Additionally, Stratfor argues that the Five Star Movement's poor performance in Emilia-Romagna may also prompt its coalition partner, the PD, to demand greater authority in the ruling alliance.

* FOMC PREVIEW: Rates are seen unchanged at 1.50-1.75%. Officials appear comfortable with the current stance, though markets still see a rate cut in 2020. A 'technical' IOER hike is possible. No SRF announcement expected, details sought. No SEP update until March. The narrative may be more pertinent for longer-term themes like balance sheet policy and the framework review. Meanwhile, perceptions about the Fed's commitment to accommodation may be a catalyst for any price moves. To download the report, please click here.

* STOCK CLOSES: SPX -1.60% AT 3243; DOW -1.57% AT 28,535; NDX -2.07% AT 8952.

* SECTORS: Cons Disc -1.53%, Cons Staples -0.32, Energy -2.77%, Financials -1.55%, Health -0.76%, Industrials -1.87%, Materials -2.11%, Real Estate -0.42%, Technology -2.36%, Communications -1.7%, Utilities -0.31%.

* CORONAVIRUS IMPACTED STOCKS: Travel focussed stocks, such as United Airlines (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwestern Airlines (LUV) are trading heavily in the red, with some holding losses of over 7% at the lows on travel disruption concerns due to the Coronavirus. Trip.com (TCOM) fell over 8% at the open, however losses pared back throughout the session and eventually traded higher. Casino names like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco (MLCO) are facing even further pressure as the confirmed cases in Macau increased to five. Copper miner Freeport McMoran (FCX) is lower as copper prices fall to 8-week lows on global growth concerns, while gold miners (GOLD, NEM) are benefitting as the precious metal rises in a safe haven bid. China listed ADR’s (BABA, JD, BIDU) also hit given the exposure to the nation. Starbucks (SBUX) and Yum China (YUMC) announced they have closed all its shops and suspended delivery service in the Hubei province. Clorox (CLX) performed well as it is a company which manufactures disinfecting wipes to help prevent the spread of disease.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Arconic (ARNC) traded higher after its earnings report despite issuing poor guidance and missing top and bottom line estimates. The co. did announce however it expects to reduce its operating costs by USD 300mln on a run rate business and that it will complete its split of its aerospace components and aluminium rolling businesses into two separate entities on April 1st. D.R Horton (DHI) an outperformer in the SPX after top and bottom line beats, as well as providing decent forecasts in Q2 above analyst expectations. AbbVie (ABBV) and Allergan (AGN) traded higher after ABBV announced it is to divest certain drugs in order to approve the merger.

* FX WRAP: DXY slightly firmer but fails to cross 98.00 to the upside in rangebound trade, hovering just above its 100dma at 97.87. CNH loses ground amid coronavirus concerns, with participants beginning to ponder the impact to growth. EUR traded within a 30-pip range against the buck with German IFO data doing little to sway the single currency. JPY and XAU firmer in a flight to quality due to the continued coronavirus concerns which saw USDJPY flirt around the 109-figure, and XAU print highs of 1586 before paring the majority of gains after gapping higher at the open. The precious metal benefited from the disease, whereas copper prices hit an 8-week low on global growth concerns. AUD and NZD lost ground due to the risk off environment to start the week, AUDUSD fell beneath 0.68 and NZDUSD beneath 0.66. EMFX was weaker across the board due to the risk off tone, however there was particular weakness in ZAR and RUB, with the latter suffering from weaker oil prices.

subject: US will today sell a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, at 1630 GMT/1130 ET), and a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, 1800 GMT/1300 ET)
content:
The US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Monday), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Monday) and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Tuesday). It will also auction a new 2-year FRN (USD 20bln, Tuesday). UBS says this week will cashflows of around USD 93bln (ex SOMA holdings, including around USD 84bln of redemptions, and around USD 9bln of coupons), implying net cashflows are around flat.

2-YEAR PREVIEW: The 2-year auction lacks set up from a relative value perspective, SocGen says, noting that the outbreak of the Coronavirus and other geopolitical risks have seen the Tplex rally in the last week. The WI yield is trading well below previous stop-out rates, and this could be a negative for the auction, as the sector richens on an outright basis. The last auction saw weak participation from foreigners, and heading into this auction, dealer holdings are relatively high at the front-end of the curve, which may limit dealer participations, which was a support at recent auctions. SocGen suggests that it should mean only tepid demand at today's auction, and sees a negative outcome. "However, fear of spread of the viral outbreak might cause the investors flee to the safety of bonds, marginally supporting the auction despite the rich outright valuations," the bank writes.

2-YEAR AUCTION RECENT HISTORY:

  • High-yield: (prev. 1.653%, six-auction average 1.634%)
  • Tail: (prev. 0.0bps, six-auction avg. -0.4bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.31x, six-auction avg. 2.57x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 32.2%, six-auction avg. 29.6%)
  • Direct: (prev. 21.5%, six-auction avg. 21.0%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 46.3%, six-auction avg. 49.4%)

 

5-YEAR PREVIEW: The 5-year sector appears to be cheap in asset swap against older 5s, and looks fair on the fly against 2s and 10s, SocGen says. The December auction was decent, amid the cheaper valuations, but for the current cycle, the sector appears rich on an outright basis, with the WI currently trading beneath 5-year auction stop-out rates. "Moreover, relatively high dealer holdings in the 3-6 year sector is not supportive of demand for the auction," SocGen writes, "notwithstanding, the specialness of the current 5-year in repo might marginally support demand," though the bank says it is still slightly negative on this auction.

US 5-YEAR AUCTION RECENT HISTORY:

  • High-yield: (prev. 1.756%, six-auction average 1.617%)
  • Tail: (prev. -1.6bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.49x, six-auction avg. 2.41x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 21.5%, six-auction avg. 24.6%)
  • Direct: (prev. 16.1%, six-auction avg. 14.6%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 62.4%, six-auction avg. 60.8%)

Daily FX Wrap: Virus woes infect EMs and high-betas; safe-havens outpace
content:
DXY

Overall a muted session for the broad Dollar and index after failing to gain much traction in the fallout of the latest coronavirus developments. Participants could be giving more credence to the impeachment trial State-side after excerpts from former National Security Advisor Bolton’s book came to light – alleging quid-pro-quo, which desks believe could increase pressure on Republican Senators to allow witnesses to be called. DXY meandered on either side of its 100 DMA (97.87) throughout the session having clocked an intraday band of 97.78-94. Looking ahead, tomorrow sees the release of December US Durable Goods figures, with the headline seen rebounding to +0.4% from -2.1%.

JPY, CHF, XAU

Conversely, safe-haven assets have latched onto their virus-induced bid; USD/JPY and EUR/CHF look to end the EU-session towards the bottom of their respective intraday ranges, with the former fluctuating on either side of the 109.00 mark vs. Friday 109.25 close (having traded in a 108.73-109.14 intraday band), whilst the latter is poised to end the session sub-1.0700 having broken below the psychological level in early EU trade. Spot gold gapped higher at the open and held onto a bulk of its gains, with prices finding resistance just shy of USD 1590/oz, having eclipsed the prior recent high of USD 1588/oz vs. Friday’s 1571/oz close. 

AUD, NZD

The marked underperformers amid the overall risk aversion in the marketplace coupled with ramifications of the coronavirus - including detrimental price action in the commodity space. AUD/USD looks to end the European session towards the bottom of its 0.6765-0.6819 range, having given up its 0.68-status ahead of potential support at 0.6755, the Nov 29th low, which also coincides with a 76.4% fib. Similarly, its Kiwi counterpart lost its 0.6600 handle and drifted to a current low of 0.6555, ahead of its 55 and 200 DMAs at 0.6550 and 0.6512 respectively. Overnight sees the release of the Australian NAB business condition, but this is unlikely to prompt much sustained action in the pair given the macro environment.

CAD, NOK, RUB

Energy-correlated FX remained pressured by the hefty losses seen in the oil complex amid the implications of the virus outbreak on global oil demand. USD/CAD looks set to end the European day towards the top of today’s current 1.3150-1.3191, having surpassed its 55 and 100 DMAs (1.3158 and 1.3178 respectively) ahead of potential barriers at the psychological 1.3200 mark. Similarly, the Norwegian Crown bled past the 10.000 level, and thereafter its 55 and 100 DMAs vs. the EUR (10.0030 and 10.0184) with the pair eyeing 10.0500 heading into the close. RUB stands as the EM underperformer amid same theme – USD/RUB extended gains above 62.000 before breaching its 55DMA to the upside (62.64) ahead of touted resistance just before the 63.000 level.

EM

Poised to end the EU session holding a lion’s share of overnight losses, led by downside in the Yuan as the coronavirus crisis claims more lives and spreads further towards the West. USD/CNH eclipsed 6.9900 to the upside topping its 200 and 55 DMAs at 6.9817 and 6.9843 respectively (albeit the pair came off highs in pixel time after the US cash open), with traders on the lookout for further virus-related headlines and potential China stimulus. Similarly, USD/TRY took multiple stabs at 5.9500 to the upside (vs. 5.9389 open). USD/ZAR hit mild resistance ~14.58 ahead of reported stops around 14.60, nonetheless the Rand heads to the end of the EU session over 1% weaker vs. the USD.

EUR, GBP

A mixed session for the Sterling and Single Currency, but relatively muted action compared to some of its G10 and EM peers. EUR/USD failed to glean much support from Italian-political developments over the weekend but saw mild pressure amid the release downbeat German Ifo Survey which reaffirmed that the German economy had a subdued start to the year. EUR/USD remained caged within a tight 1.1015-35 band with only ECB’s Lane tomorrow’s scheduled pertinent event for the Single Currency. Cable found an overnight base at 1.3050 and initially took advantage of some weakness seen in the Single Currency post-Ifo. Cable has since given up the mild gains and heads to the EU close flat just above 1.3050.

subject: UK PM Johnson on Huawei says we want to have 5G, but without compromising national security, and without compromising national security or Five Eyes intelligence cooperation
analysis_details:
• NOTE: the Five Eyes group is an anglophone intelligence alliance comprising Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States - as such, it would initially appear that the UK is looking to appease US concerns, which has argued that UK sovereignty would be at risk if it allowed Huawei to build its 5G network. 
  • UK set to announce 5G decision on Tuesday, according to earlier reports

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC rate decision at 1900 GMT/1400 ET on 29th January 2020; Powell press conference at 1930 GMT/1430 ET
content:
• Rates are seen unchanged at 1.50-1.75%. Officials appear comfortable with the current stance, though markets still see a rate cut in 2020. A 'technical' IOER hike is possible. No SRF announcement expected, details sought. No SEP update until March. The narrative may be more pertinent for longer-term themes like balance sheet policy and the framework review. Meanwhile, perceptions about the Fed's commitment to accommodation may be a catalyst for any price moves. To download the report, please click here.

content: • Sanella says priority will be given to the Zawia refinery (120k BPD) with crude availability

subject: Equities in the red due to ongoing Coronavirus concerns as the confirmed cases reach over 2700 and the death toll hits 80
content:
Individual movers

Gainers

  • Arconic (ARNC) +2.2% after its earnings report
  • D.R Horton (DHI) +2.2% on top and bottom line beats, as well as decent forecasts
  • AbbVie (ABBV) +2.1% as it is to divest a number of drugs for its Allergan (AGN) merger, whilst it also announced China is testing one of its HIV drugs for a Coronavirus treatment.

Losers

  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) -7.2% on Coronavirus concerns in Macau, whilst also being downgraded at Bank of America
  • Las Vegas Sands (LVS) -7% as Coronavirus cases increase in Macau
  • American Airlines (AAL) -8% due to China travel concerns from the Coronavirus
analysis_details:
• The Coronavirus continues to be the main driver to start the week as global cases reach over 2700 and deaths toll now around 80. Travel focussed stocks, such as United Airlines (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwestern Airlines (LUV) are trading heavily in the red, with some holding losses of over 7% on travel disruption concerns, as is Trip.com (TCOM). Casino names like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco (MLCO) are facing even further pressure as the confirmed cases in Macau increased to five. Copper miner Freeport McMoran (FCX) is lower as copper prices fall to 8-week lows on global growth concerns, while gold miners (GOLD, NEM) are benefitting as the precious metal rises in a safe haven bid. China listed ADR’s (BABA, JD, BIDU) also hit given the exposure to the nation.
  • Sectors take a defensive tone with Technology underperforming given the exposure to China, and Energy also heavily in the red as crude prices continue to fall on demand concerns, weighing on producers. On the flipside, Utilities remain flat, but it is outperforming given the defensive nature of the sector, as is Consumer Staples and Health Care, with the former -0.3%, and the latter -1%.

Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 27th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) and Yum China Holdings (YUMC) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) have closed all its shops and suspended delivery service in the Hubei province due to the coronavirus.
  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) / Allergan, Plc (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) agreed to divest its Brazikumab and Zenpep drugs, where  Nestle (NESN SW) will take ownership of Zenpep, and AstraZeneca (AZN) will acquire Brazikumab. The approval of the deals is  dependent upon FTC and EC approval.
  • D. R. Horton (DHI) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.16 (exp. 0.92), Revenue 4.02bln (exp. 3.77bln),  homes closed +13% to 12,959. CEO believes they will continue to see good demand across their markets

27th January 2020

US equity futures are falling ahead of the cash open given the continued coronavirus contagion which saw the global cases reach 2700 and the deaths toll topped 80 over the weekend. Travel focussed stocks, such as United Airlines (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwestern Airlines (LUV) are trading in the red, with some holding losses of over 4% on travel disruption concerns, as is Trip.com (TCOM). Casino names like Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco (MLCO) are facing even further pressure as the confirmed cases in Macau increased to five. Copper miner Freeport McMoran (FCX) is lower as copper prices fall to 8-week lows on global growth concerns, while gold miners (GOLD, NEM) are benefitting as the precious metal rises in a safe haven bid. China listed ADR’s (BABA, JD, BIDU) also hit as the death toll increases.

This week’s Barron’s articles highlight that the Super Bowl will be a huge opportunity for sports betting names, as it focuses on expansion in mobile sports betting, highlighting that the street has been enthusiastic in the rising stock price in Diamond Eagle Acquisition (DEAC). Further on the Super Bowl, Barron’s says that advertisers like Omnicom (OMC) and Interpublic Group (IPG) hold less appeal, amid a further inflow of larger tech names partaking in the advertising space. Elsewhere the journalists highlight that largest tech companies such as Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) are competing for a larger share in esports. Finally, Barron’s notes investors in HP (HPQ) are likely to benefit as it has made it clear it would prefer to lever up and buy back large amounts of shares, instead of submitting an offer to Xerox (XRX).

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) – Ahead of its earnings on Tuesday, Credit Suisse analyst Matthew Cabral is looking for continued improvements in iPhone revenue trends due to a strong start for the iPhone 11. However, he believes the focus is shifting to the upcoming 5G iPhone in H2 20, which should help it drive revenue growth. Elsewhere, RBC Capital analyst Muller maintains an outperform rating on the tech giant with a USD 330 PT (last closing price 318.31). The analyst states his data checks suggest its estimates for Q1 are reasonable, whilst highlighting a slight beat on consensus figures could be seen due to strength in iPhone and wearable sales.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) – A Boeing jet reportedly crashed in Ghazni, Afghanistan, which was operated by Ariana Afghan. The number of casualties is currently unclear, however, separate reports state the airline denied the crash. Elsewhere, Boeing successfully staged its first flight of its 777X jet.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) raised its Guyana offshore estimate to above 8ln BoE as it continues to develop the Guyana oil block.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been downgraded to Market Perform from Outperform at Northland, with a USD 70 PT (last closing price: 68.47). Analyst Gus Richard notes that while he forecasts several both positive and negative catalysts, he is unclear what will come first. The analyst expects Intel to fix or jettison underperforming product lines, although sees headwinds which could impact the stock, perhaps as soon as Q2 2020. Gus Richard highlights structural issues, including its design flow and manufacturing.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class A (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – US State Attorney Generals are to meet with the DoJ to collaborate information on a probe which relates to the co.’s monopolistic behaviour for online advertising which could harm consumers, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Kraft Heinz Co (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) CEO is pushing for growth, noting its aim is for fewer and bolder bets to increase its sales, according to WSJ.
  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) and Yum China Holdings (YUMC) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) have closed all its shops and suspended delivery service in the Hubei province due to the coronavirus.
  • T-Mobile (TMUS)/Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) are reportedly facing a potential hurdle from the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC), the only remaining state utilities board to not approve the deal, according to WSJ, who note the CPUC is continuing its review which threatens to further delay or even derail the USD 26bln merger.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that China is testing an HIV drug as a treatment for the coronavirus.
  • AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) / Allergan, Plc (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) agreed to divest its Brazikumab and Zenpep drugs, where Nestle (NESN SW) will take ownership of Zenpep, and AstraZeneca (AZN) will acquire Brazikumab. The approval of the deals is dependent upon FTC and EC approval.
  • Arconic Inc. (ARNC) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) Q4 19 (USD) Adj. EPS 0.53 (exp. 0.54), revenue 3.4bln (exp. 3.48bln). Forecasts FY20 Adj. EPS between 2.22-2.42 (exp. 2.37), revenue expected between 13.9bln – 14.2bln (exp. 14.16bln). Q1 20 Adj. EPS forecast 0.47 – 0.53 (exp. 0.53)
  • Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has been upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS, raising the PT to USD 900 from USD 690 (Last closing price USD 869.71). Where analyst Dennis Geiger is more confident in the sustainability of the company’s strong sales and earnings growth, highlighting recent performance has significantly exceeded his expectations.
  • D. R. Horton (DHI) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.16 (exp. 0.92), Revenue 4.02bln (exp. 3.77bln), homes closed +13% to 12,959. CEO believes they will continue to see good demand across their markets. FY20 revenue forecast at 18.5bln to 19bln (exp. 18.82bln, prev. 18.5bln – 19.1bln) FY20 home closes expected to be between 60,000 and 61,500 (prev. 60,000 to 61,000). Expects Q2 revenue at USD 4.25 - 4.4bln (exp. 4.25bln) and Q2 home sales between 13,800 and 14,300 homes.
  • Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Incyte (INCY) announced its BREEZE-AD4 trial, evaluating Baricitinib in combination with Topical Corticosteroids for treatment of adults with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis met its primary endpoint.
  • Marathon Petroleum (MPC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) increased its quarterly dividend to USD 0.58, a 9.4% increase.
  • Simon Property Group Inc (SPG) (Real Estate/Retail REITs) is reportedly considering teaming with Authentic Brands to look at an acquisition of Forever 21, the bankrupt teen retailer, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Sprint (S) (Communication Services / Wireless Telecommunication Services) Q3 19 (USD): EPS -0.03 (exp. -0.05), Revenue 8.08bln (exp. 8.22bln); wireless post-paid net additions 494,000 (prev. 309,000); wireless post-paid ARPU 42.04 (exp. 42.30). Sprint is optimistic about the necessary regulatory steps to complete merger with T-Mobile (TMUS, DTE GY), Sees Q4 EBITDA to remain flat sequentially. Capex seen around USD 1bln in Q4.
  • Yum! Brands Inc (YUM) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) increased its quarterly dividend to USD 0.47 from USD 0.42/shr.

OTHER

  • Crispr Therapeutics (CRSP) (Health Care/Biotechnology) had a stake cut to 6.2% from 7.3% by Bayer Global Investments.
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) urged a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit from General Motors (GM) which accused the automaker of racketeering and bribing UAW officials to put General Motors (GM) at a multibillion-dollar labour cost disadvantage.

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • BIOGEN (BIIB) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT CANACCORD
  • BUSINESS FIRST BANCSHARES (BSFT) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT STEPHENS
  • CENTERPOINT ENERGY (CNP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM IN LINE AT EVERCORE ISI
  • CHEWY (CHWY) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT WEDBUSH
  • CHIPOTLE (CMG) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT UBS
  • DENALI THERAPEUTICS (DNLI) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS
  • DTE ENERGY (DTE) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM IN LINE AT EVERCORE ISI
  • E.L.F. BEAUTY (ELF) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

subject: The Desk is monitoring Trump impeachment proceedings more closely after weekend news that Bolton alleges aid was tied to investigations
content:
• Traders would be wise to begin paying attention to impeachment proceedings. Previously, the market was happy to dismiss it as noise, given that Trump has the support of the GOP controlled Senate, where a two-thirds majority is required to convict the President.
  • However, a NY Times article over the weekend, citing excerpts from former National Securities Advisor Bolton's upcoming book, alledges that Trump wanted to continue freezing funds for security assistance to Ukraine until officials there helped with investigations into Democrats, including Democrat Presidential candidate Joe Bidens.
  • UBS said the news would undermine the central argument put forward by Trump's defense, and will likely increase the pressure on Republican senators to allow witnesses to be called.
  • For what it is worth, Trump has already tweeted on the matter, stating he never told Bolton to tie aid to investigations into Democrats, and "in fact, he never complained about this at the time of his very public termination. If John Bolton said this, it was only to sell a book."
  • The WSJ said it was not immediately clear how much the revelations could impact the debate on calling trial witnesses, and it was almost certain not to shift the expectation that Trump won't be convicted, noting that Four Republicans would have to join with all Democrats to make that happen.
  • However, the desk is now more closely monitoring the impeachment proceedings, ahead of the ramp up in 2020 election news flow next week, when the Primary Season gets going.

US will today sell a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, at 1630 GMT/1130 ET), and a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, 1800 GMT/1300 ET)
content:
The US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Monday), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Monday) and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Tuesday). It will also auction a new 2-year FRN (USD 20bln, Tuesday). UBS says this week will cashflows of around USD 93bln (ex SOMA holdings, including around USD 84bln of redemptions, and around USD 9bln of coupons), implying net cashflows are around flat.

2-YEAR PREVIEW: The 2-year auction lacks set up from a relative value perspective, SocGen says, noting that the outbreak of the Coronavirus and other geopolitical risks have seen the Tplex rally in the last week. The WI yield is trading well below previous stop-out rates, and this could be a negative for the auction, as the sector richens on an outright basis. The last auction saw weak participation from foreigners, and heading into this auction, dealer holdings are relatively high at the front-end of the curve, which may limit dealer participations, which was a support at recent auctions. SocGen suggests that it should mean only tepid demand at today's auction, and sees a negative outcome. "However, fear of spread of the viral outbreak might cause the investors flee to the safety of bonds, marginally supporting the auction despite the rich outright valuations," the bank writes.

2-YEAR AUCTION RECENT HISTORY: 

  • High-yield: (prev. 1.653%, six-auction average 1.634%)
  • Tail: (prev. 0.0bps, six-auction avg. -0.4bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.31x, six-auction avg. 2.57x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 32.2%, six-auction avg. 29.6%)
  • Direct: (prev. 21.5%, six-auction avg. 21.0%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 46.3%, six-auction avg. 49.4%)

5-YEAR PREVIEW: The 5-year sector appears to be cheap in asset swap against older 5s, and looks fair on the fly against 2s and 10s, SocGen says. The December auction was decent, amid the cheaper valuations, but for the current cycle, the sector appears rich on an outright basis, with the WI currently trading beneath 5-year auction stop-out rates. "Moreover, relatively high dealer holdings in the 3-6 year sector is not supportive of demand for the auction," SocGen writes, "notwithstanding, the specialness of the current 5-year in repo might marginally support demand," though the bank says it is still slightly negative on this auction.

US 5-YEAR AUCTION RECENT HISTORY: 

  • High-yield: (prev. 1.756%, six-auction average 1.617%)
  • Tail: (prev. -1.6bps, six-auction avg. -0.1bps)
  • Bid-to-cover: (prev. 2.49x, six-auction avg. 2.41x)
  • Dealers: (prev. 21.5%, six-auction avg. 24.6%)
  • Direct: (prev. 16.1%, six-auction avg. 14.6%)
  • Indirect: (prev. 62.4%, six-auction avg. 60.8%)

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Risk-off remains as coronavirus concerns continue to weigh
  • China’s National Health Commission confirmed 2744 cases of coronavirus and death toll at 80 as of the end of January 26th
  • China extended the Lunar New Year holiday to February 2nd to contain the coronavirus; unclear if market closures will follow suit
  • Italy’s Centre-Left bloc defeated Salvini’s league in Emilia-Romagna, with BTP’s substantially outperforming as such
  • FX space is mixed vs. a modestly firmer USD, with safe havens stronger and antipodeans weaker on virus concerns
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales, ECB’s Mersch, US 2 and 5yr supply
  • Earnings: Allergan, Dover, Arconic, Whirlpool, Juniper

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE – Newsquawk analysis on headline feed

China warned that the coronavirus is getting stronger and the number of cases could increase, while China’s National Health Commission confirmed 2744 cases of coronavirus and death toll at 80 as of the end of January 26th. (Sky News/Newswires)

China extended the Lunar New Year holiday to February 2nd to contain the coronavirus, while other reports noted that Wuhan has suspended visa and passport services for Chinese citizens until January 30th. However, a twitter source suggested that 5mln people had left Wuhan prior to China’s lockdown taking effect. (Newswires/Twitter)

China Global Times notes that a couple formerly infected with coronavirus recovered after 10 days' treatment, the couple now tests negative for the virus. (Twitter)

US confirmed the country’s 5th coronavirus case, while it was reportedly arranging a charter flight to evacuate its diplomats and citizens from Wuhan. Australia also confirmed a 5th case of coronavirus, while France declared the first 2 cases of the virus and the French Health Minister noted it is likely there will be others. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

A broad risk-averse tone resumed across asset classes following on from last Friday’s declines on Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst weekly performance since August amid ongoing coronavirus fears, with the number of confirmed cases stateside now at 5. Furthermore, the latest official update from China stated the number of infected rose to 2744 with the death toll at 80, and China also warned that the coronavirus is getting stronger and the amount of cases could increase. This heavily pressured US equity futures which slipped around 1% in early trade and spurred safe-haven bids for T-notes and gold, while Nikkei 225 (-2.0%) sold off due to the virus outbreak fears, detrimental currency flows and against the backdrop of thinned conditions with nearly all major bourses in the region closed for holiday. India’s NIFTY (-1.0%) was also lower after large-scale protests yesterday regarding the Citizenship Amendment Act, but with losses limited amid corporate earnings including ICICI Bank. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned on safe-haven buying due to the coronavirus jitters which also spurred T-notes to gap higher by about 10 ticks at the re-open, although the upward momentum for JGBs has since petered out amid the lack of BoJ presence in the market and absence of most regional participants.

China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission is to encourage banks to appropriately reduce lending rates for sectors heavily impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

US 

US President Trump’s administration widened its steel and aluminium tariffs to include certain imported nails, staples, electrical wires and some downstream components used in autos and tractors. In other news, US President Trump said US could save 50% on drugs purchased from abroad and that the administration will announce drug price policy changes soon. (Newswires)

Former National Security Adviser Bolton’s unpublished book stated that President Trump told him in August that he wanted to continue freezing security aid to Ukraine until they helped with investigations into Democrats including the Bidens. However, US President Trump later tweeted that he never told Bolton the aid to Ukraine was tied to investigations into Democrats, including the Bidens and that if John Bolton said this, it was to sell a book. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson is expected to decide as early as this week regarding US request to ban Huawei from the UK 5G network which could impact the UK-US "special relationship". (Axios) The Times speculates that this decision could be announced on Tuesday.

UK Brexit Secretary Barclay said the UK will layout more details next month regarding its objective for a free trade agreement with the EU. (Newswires) US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin sad the US hopes to complete a trade agreement with the UK by year-end. (WSJ)

The EY Item Club has lifted its UK 2020 GDP forecast from 1% to 1.2% and raised 2021 to 1.7% from 1.5%, whilst “urging” the BoE to not cut rates this week; suggests policymakers should “wait and see” on the basis that growth is expected to improve. (Times)

EU is to request its partners around the world to temporarily treat UK as part of the bloc as it tries to navigate through the transition period, according to reports citing a diplomatic note which is to be sent to over 160 countries. (FT) EU will reportedly be tough regarding state aid for companies in which member states are determined to restrict Britain's ability to support key industries through state funds as a price for agreeing a trade deal. (FT)

Italy's Centre-Left bloc, led by the Democratic Party are set to defeat Matteo Salvini’s League in the Emilia Romagna regional election, resulting in a much-needed victory for PM Conte’s coalition government and therefore has dampened the likelihood of a snap election. Note, the League is set for an easy win in Calabria, however, this is seen as a less significant vote. (Newswires)

Fitch raised Greece to BB from BB-; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive, while it affirmed Finland at AA+; Outlook revised to Stable from Positive. (Newswires)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Jan) 95.9 vs. Exp. 97 (Prev. 96.3); Expectations New (Jan) 92.9 vs. Exp. 95 (Prev. 93.8, Rev. 93.9); Current Conditions New (Jan) 99.1 vs. Exp. 99.2 (Prev. 98.8)

-        Ifo notes that the German economy had a subdued start to the year

-        Demand has increased in the industrial sector, there is reason to be cautiously optimistic

-        Expects German economy to grow 0.2% in Q1

GEOPOLITICS

Iran nuclear agency deputy chief said they have the capacity to enrich uranium at any percentage if the government decides to. (Newswires)

There was an attack on the US embassy in Baghdad, Iraq where 3 rockets hit the embassy which left one individual injured although the injuries were only minor and the person later returned to duty, while the US embassy is said to have informed the Iraqi government that there will be a military response according to Twitter sources. (Newswires)

Cyberattacks which targeted European and Middle Eastern government are believed to be hackers acting in the interests of the Turkish government, sources state. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European stocks see hefty losses across the board [Eurostoxx 50 -2.2%] following muted but negative APAC session as the region experiences mass holiday closures. For reference, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index sees around 95% of its stocks in negative territory. UK’s FTSE 100 (-2.5%) sees slightly more pronounced downside amid heavy-bleeding from large-cap miners and energy names, in-fitting with price action in the respective complexes - Rio Tino (-4.8%), Antofagasta (-4.3%), Anglo American (-4.5%), Glencore (-4.5%), BP (-2.0%) and Shell (-2.0%).  Meanwhile, Italy’s FTSE MIB (-0.7%) fares better in light of the aftermath from the Emilia Romagna regional elections which diminished the chances of an Italian snap election, thus Italian banks cushion losses in the index with tailwinds from favourable BTP price action – Ubi Banca (+0.1%), Banco BPM (+0.1%), Intesa Sanpaolo (-0.1%). Sectors are broadly, but firmly in the red, with Materials (-2.8%) lagging amid the base-metal price action. Defensives meanwhile see losses to a lesser extent than their cyclical peers. Consumer discretionary names also remain a laggard amid the demand implications from the virus outbreak for luxury goods and travel names, such as: Swatch (-3.6%), Richemont (-3.0%), IAG (-6.0%) and easyJet (-5.5%). In terms of individual movers; William Hill (-1.7%) saw losses at the open amid a breakdown in expansion talks with CBS Sports. Bayer (-1.5%) conforms to losses seen in the region despite a pushback from a spokesperson regarding last-week’s sources reports of an imminent settlement to its Roundup weedkiller scandal. On the flip side, positive broker moves see RWE (+0.1%), Uniper (+0.1%) Orsted (+0.1%) and Italgas (+1.4%) in the green.

FX

EM - Broad losses experienced in the EM-sphere, led by downside in the Yuan as the coronavirus crisis claims more lives and spreads further towards the West (full analysis available on the Newsquawk feed). USD/CNH has gained traction and breached 6.9800 to the upside (vs. 6.9400 low), topping its 200 and 55 DMAs at 6.9817 and 6.9843 respectively – with talks of potential stimulus measures by the Chinese Government to cushion the economic impact of the outbreak. TRY and ZAR feel the Yuan contagion with USD/TRY looking for a test of 5.9500 to the upside whilst USD/ZAR inches closer to 14.6000, but could see mild resistance at 14.5970 (21st Jan high) with reported stops above the round figure and ahead its 200 DMA at 14.6105.

CAD, NOK, RUB - Energy-related FX succumb to losses seen in the complex as jitters materialise regarding the implications of the virus outbreak on global oil demand. The Rouble remains the most impacted as USD/RUB surpasses 62.50 (vs. 62.24 open) before stopping short of its 200 DMA (62.63). The Loonie meanwhile extends losses vs. the Buck as the pair found support ~1.3150 before taking out its 55 and 100 DMAs (at 1.3158 and 1.3178 respectively) ahead of the psychological 1.3200. Similarly, Norway’s oil-correlated Crown drifted lower since the open – EUR/NOK reclaimed 10.0000 (which also coincides with its 55DMA) to the upside and topped its 100 DMA (10.0183) – with potential resistance touted at 10.0500.

AUD, NZD - The antipodeans also drift in tandem with the risk aversion and headwinds from detrimental base metal price action amid the aforementioned virus woes. AUD/USD has given up its 0.6800-status as losses exacerbated amid the domino-effect coronavirus would have on the Australian economy via China’s anticipated economic slowdown – with reports noting that Chinese GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt. The pair remains the marked G10 underperformer thus far and eyes 0.6755 (26th Nov low and 76.4% Fibo of the Oct to Dec move) to the downside for a potential support level, and with some AUD 800mln in options seen expiring at strike 0.6765. Meanwhile, its Kiwi counterpart looks to test its 55 DMA to the downside at 0.6550.

JPY, DXY - Safe haven flows have seen an early bid in the Japanese currency, as USD/JPY gapped below 109.00 at the open vs. Friday’s 109.25 close. Since then, the pair has fluctuated on either side of the round figure having found a base around 108.75, and with technicians eyeing 108.67 (100 DMA) and 108.52 (200 DMA) should the base fail to hold, and with 109.00 seeing circa USD 800mln in options expiries. DXY meanwhile remains flat intraday having notched a current range of 97.800-941 and with little by way of schedule data/speakers to sway the state of play.

EUR, GBP - Mixed session for the Sterling and Single Currency, but relatively muted action compared to some of its G10 and EM peers. EUR/USD saw some pressure amid a downbeat German Ifo Survey which reaffirmed that the German economy has a subdued start to the year, but somewhat echoed Markit’s assessment that the manufacturing sector is slowly emerging from its downturn. EUR/USD failed to glean much reprieve from the development in Italy after the Centre-Left bloc defeated Salvini’s league in regional elections, thus dimming the chances of a snap election. The pair hovers just above 1.1000, having clocked in a current range of 1.1015-35. Meanwhile, Cable found an overnight base at 1.3050 and took advantage of some weakness seen in the Single Currency. EUR/GBP drifts further below 0.8450 whilst GBP/USD meanders just under 1.3100, having eclipsed the level in recent trade.

Notable Expriries, NY Cut:

-        AUD/USD: 0.6765 (800M), 0.6880 (230M)

-        USD/JPY: 109.00 (805M), 110.50 (300M)

FIXED

Debt is broadly lifted this morning on coronavirus concerns, with a full analysis piece available on the Newsquawk headline feed, as the risk-off theme continues to dominate. Coronavirus aside, Italian debt is firmer by over 200bp at present as the left-wing bloc successfully repelled Salvini’s League in the Emilia Romagna regional election; Democratic Party took 51.4% and the League’s coalition 43.7%, and as such significantly reduces the chances of another general election. Price action which has sent the BTP-Bund yield spread below 140 (tested 138.0 at best) thus far, to levels not seen since September/October’19. Technically speaking, for BTP’s resistance lies at 147.13 and then clear-air until 147.86; after-which very little is present before 150.00. Periphery aside, core debt is firmer on the aforementioned broad macro theme, for Bunds resistance lies just above 174 at 174.05, which coincides with the 31st October high and the 50DMA (currently, 173.88 at best). Moving to the States where an incredibly quiet calendar provides little inspiration on a macro perspective; however, this week seen the largest number of US Co’s reporting earnings, which will provide insight into the economy’s health – as well as the FOMC on Wednesday. USTs are bid in a similar fashion to European bonds with yields suppressed, 10-year yield having convincingly relinquished the 1.70 mark to the downside overnight, with a test of 1.60 now perhaps on the cards if this morning’s price action continues.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue their downward trajectory amid the materialising concerns surrounding the virus outbreak’s impact on global growth, oil demand and overall sentiment. While some desks have drawn comparisons to the SARS virus in 2003, which trimmed 0.15ppts off of global growth, some believe that the comparisons may be slightly unfair, albeit some economists note that Chinese GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt. WTI Mar’20 futures gapped lower at the open before downside exacerbated and prompted the contract to test levels close to USD 52/bbl to the downside, levels last seen in October 2019. Similarly, Brent Mar’20 surrendered the USD 60/bbl handle and currently posts loses around USD 2/bbl; the contract did find some support at USD 58.50/bbl. Elsewhere spot gold is bolstered by the flows in to safe-havens, with prices testing USD 1590/oz to the upside during APAC trade vs. Friday’s ~USD 1570/oz. The overall demand/global growth aspect of the outbreak of the coronavirus has led to sharp losses in base metal prices: copper slumped around 2% at one point and dipped below USD 2.62/lb vs. Friday’s ~USD 2.67/lb close, whilst iron ore futures fell as much as 6% at one point.

Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz said they are closely observing developments in the global oil market resulting from gloomy expectations regarding impact from coronavirus, while he added that Saudi and OPEC+ producers have the capability and flexibility required to respond to any developments by taking necessary action to support oil market stability if required. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said the country's compliance with the OPEC pact has exceeded 100%. (Newswires)

On the flip side, positive broker moves see RWE (+0.1%), Uniper (+0.1%) Orsted (+0.1%) and Italgas (+1.4%) in the green.

FX

EM - Broad losses experienced in the EM-sphere, led by downside in the Yuan as the coronavirus crisis claims more lives and spreads further towards the West (full analysis available on the Newsquawk feed). USD/CNH has gained traction and breached 6.9800 to the upside (vs. 6.9400 low), topping its 200 and 55 DMAs at 6.9817 and 6.9843 respectively – with talks of potential stimulus measures by the Chinese Government to cushion the economic impact of the outbreak. TRY and ZAR feel the Yuan contagion with USD/TRY looking for a test of 5.9500 to the upside whilst USD/ZAR inches closer to 14.6000, but could see mild resistance at 14.5970 (21st Jan high) with reported stops above the round figure and ahead its 200 DMA at 14.6105.

CAD, NOK, RUB - Energy-related FX succumb to losses seen in the complex as jitters materialise regarding the implications of the virus outbreak on global oil demand. The Rouble remains the most impacted as USD/RUB surpasses 62.50 (vs. 62.24 open) before stopping short of its 200 DMA (62.63). The Loonie meanwhile extends losses vs. the Buck as the pair found support ~1.3150 before taking out its 55 and 100 DMAs (at 1.3158 and 1.3178 respectively) ahead of the psychological 1.3200. Similarly, Norway’s oil-correlated Crown drifted lower since the open – EUR/NOK reclaimed 10.0000 (which also coincides with its 55DMA) to the upside and topped its 100 DMA (10.0183) – with potential resistance touted at 10.0500.

AUD, NZD - The antipodeans also drift in tandem with the risk aversion and headwinds from detrimental base metal price action amid the aforementioned virus woes. AUD/USD has given up its 0.6800-status as losses exacerbated amid the domino-effect coronavirus would have on the Australian economy via China’s anticipated economic slowdown – with reports noting that Chinese GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt. The pair remains the marked G10 underperformer thus far and eyes 0.6755 (26th Nov low and 76.4% Fibo of the Oct to Dec move) to the downside for a potential support level, and with some AUD 800mln in options seen expiring at strike 0.6765. Meanwhile, its Kiwi counterpart looks to test its 55 DMA to the downside at 0.6550.

JPY, DXY - Safe haven flows have seen an early bid in the Japanese currency, as USD/JPY gapped below 109.00 at the open vs. Friday’s 109.25 close. Since then, the pair has fluctuated on either side of the round figure having found a base around 108.75, and with technicians eyeing 108.67 (100 DMA) and 108.52 (200 DMA) should the base fail to hold, and with 109.00 seeing circa USD 800mln in options expiries. DXY meanwhile remains flat intraday having notched a current range of 97.800-941 and with little by way of schedule data/speakers to sway the state of play.

EUR, GBP - Mixed session for the Sterling and Single Currency, but relatively muted action compared to some of its G10 and EM peers. EUR/USD saw some pressure amid a downbeat German Ifo Survey which reaffirmed that the German economy has a subdued start to the year, but somewhat echoed Markit’s assessment that the manufacturing sector is slowly emerging from its downturn. EUR/USD failed to glean much reprieve from the development in Italy after the Centre-Left bloc defeated Salvini’s league in regional elections, thus dimming the chances of a snap election. The pair hovers just above 1.1000, having clocked in a current range of 1.1015-35. Meanwhile, Cable found an overnight base at 1.3050 and took advantage of some weakness seen in the Single Currency. EUR/GBP drifts further below 0.8450 whilst GBP/USD meanders just under 1.3100, having eclipsed the level in recent trade.

FIXED INCOME

Debt is broadly lifted this morning on coronavirus concerns, with a full analysis piece available on the Newsquawk headline feed, as the risk-off theme continues to dominate. Coronavirus aside, Italian debt is firmer by over 200bp at present as the left-wing bloc successfully repelled Salvini’s League in the Emilia Romagna regional election; Democratic Party took 51.4% and the League’s coalition 43.7%, and as such significantly reduces the chances of another general election. Price action which has sent the BTP-Bund yield spread below 140 (tested 138.0 at best) thus far, to levels not seen since September/October’19. Technically speaking, for BTP’s resistance lies at 147.13 and then clear-air until 147.86; after-which very little is present before 150.00. Periphery aside, core debt is firmer on the aforementioned broad macro theme, for Bunds resistance lies just above 174 at 174.05, which coincides with the 31st October high and the 50DMA (currently, 173.88 at best). Moving to the States where an incredibly quiet calendar provides little inspiration on a macro perspective; however, this week seen the largest number of US Co’s reporting earnings, which will provide insight into the economy’s health – as well as the FOMC on Wednesday. USTs are bid in a similar fashion to European bonds with yields suppressed, 10-year yield having convincingly relinquished the 1.70 mark to the downside overnight, with a test of 1.60 now perhaps on the cards if this morning’s price action continues.

COMMODITIES                                                              

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue their downward trajectory amid the materialising concerns surrounding the virus outbreak’s impact on global growth, oil demand and overall sentiment. While some desks have drawn comparisons to the SARS virus in 2003, which trimmed 0.15ppts off of global growth, some believe that the comparisons may be slightly unfair, albeit some economists note that Chinese GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt. WTI Mar’20 futures gapped lower at the open before downside exacerbated and prompted the contract to test levels close to USD 52/bbl to the downside, levels last seen in October 2019. Similarly, Brent Mar’20 surrendered the USD 60/bbl handle and currently posts loses around USD 2/bbl; the contract did find some support at USD 58.50/bbl. Elsewhere spot gold is bolstered by the flows in to safe-havens, with prices testing USD 1590/oz to the upside during APAC trade vs. Friday’s ~USD 1570/oz. The overall demand/global growth aspect of the outbreak of the coronavirus has led to sharp losses in base metal prices: copper slumped around 2% at one point and dipped below USD 2.62/lb vs. Friday’s ~USD 2.67/lb close, whilst iron ore futures fell as much as 6% at one point.

subject: UAE Energy Minister said the country's compliance with the OPEC pact has exceeded 100%
GS says neither history, positioning, nor valuation shows cause for panic; sees S&P 500 trading sideways until election, ending 2020 at 3400
content:
• HISTORY: The S&P 500 has risen 11% in the last 3-months, led by a 22% rally in tech, and similar surges have not signaled the end of the bull market. Over the last 3-months, the returns/realised volatility ratio has been 1.7; Looking at 3-month periods with that ratio at 1.5 or greater, the median S&P 500 return during the next month was -0.2%, but the median 3-month and 12-month returns were +6% and +13%.
  • POSITIONING: Positioning data is muddy. Current institutional investor positioning screens as extremely elevated, but US households have declined to embrace the recent rally.
  • VALUATION: Valuations, not earnings, have been driving the rally. S&P 500 forward P/E is 19.3x vs. 17.6x 3-months ago, and 15.0x at the start of 2019. Meanwhile, consensus 2020 EPS has been lowered by 2% since the start of Q4, and forecasts 9% EPS growth this year. GS sees 6% EPS growth, so believes further downward revisions are likely to the consensus.
  • VALUATIONS JUSTIFIED: Macro environment is supportive of valuations, GS says. US and global growth data has stabilised, and the US/China trade deal reduces downside risk to global growth. Fed funds futures show that the market continues to expect the Fed will remain on hold this year, and 10-year US Treasury yields have remained below 2%. GS' model indicates that the current 340bps 'yield gap' between the S&P 500 EPS yield and Treasury yield is in line with fair value.
  • ELECTION PRESENTS RISKS: The Presidential race will likely provide some headwind to multiples. Historically, S&P 500 valuations have declined ahead of elections alongside an increase in economic policy uncertainty, and GS estimates that a 25bps rise in 10-year Treasury yields would lower S&P 500 P/E to 18.5x from its current 19.3x.
  • MARKET BREADTH: GS says market breadth does not appear to be a major risk. While IT (+22% over 3-months) accounts for 45% of the S&P 500 return (with one-fifth attributable just to AAPL at +32% and MSFT at +22%), strength within IT was broad-based: Semis, Hardware, and Software & Services sub-sectors have all outperformed, as have Health Care and CommServices sectors (24% of the S&P 500).
  • CONCENTRATION: Instead, GS argues that market concentration is more concerning. The five largest stocks currently account for 17% of S&P 500 market cap, the highest in the last 30 years outside of the Tech Bubble - any shock to any of these companies (AAPL, MSFT, GOOGL, AMZN, FB) could pose a major headwind to aggregate S&P 500 index performance, GS argues, a risk that is heightened by the regulatory and factor exposures shared by these stocks.
  • ECONOMIC GROWTH: One bullish argument is GS economists' expectation that US growth will accelerate in H1 2020; industrials have lagged but should outperform if GDP growth accelerates, the bank believes. S&P 500 Industrials stocks with above-average betas to US economic data surprises during the last two years include: EXPD, UAL, CAT, BA, FAST, ALK, JBHT, UPS, HON, FDX, LUV, DOV, UNP, NLSN, GE, CTAS, NSC, ODFL, LMT, VRSK, EFX, NOC, LHX, TDG.
  • YEAR-END TARGET: The S&P 500 is already within 3% of its year-end target, and investors must now evaluate whether to raise expectations, or cut risk. GS argues that while most positive catalysts already appear embedded in the S&P 500 price, neither history, positioning, nor valuation shows cause for panic. GS continues to expect the S&P 500 will trade sideways near 3250 ahead of the election in November, but rally to 3400 by year-end (current consensus is 3355 for year-end 2020).

ANALYSIS: CORONAVIRUS UPDATE & IMPACT
content:
*CURRENT SCALE

  • China’s National Health Commission has confirmed 2744 cases of the virus, and the death toll has now increased to 80 as of January 26th; additionally, over 30k individuals are under observation.
  • Outside of China, the US has confirmed their 5th case (a further 63 are being monitored), as have Australia, while France have confirmed their first two cases. Additionally, the US are reportedly preparing for a charter flight to evacuate its citizens from Wuhan; similarly, measures have been touted for UK citizens, though nothing is confirmed for either group as of yet. France and Japan have expressed a desire to do the same as well.
  • Other countries with reported cases thus far include: Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam, Nepal and Canada
  • (16:50 GMT) The CDC later announced that no further cases have been seen in the US, and that there is currently no evidence of transmission from imported goods, whilst at this stage the immediate risk to the US is low 

*VIRUS’ DEVELOPMENT

  • China’s Minister of National Health Commission Xiaowei has stated that the virus, which differs from SARS, can be contagious throughout its incubation period; a period which averages 10-days but can vary from 1-14, with authorities adding that they do not yet have the virus fully under control.
  • Clinical trials are currently progressing using ritonavir and lopinavir, anti-HIV drugs, as a potential treatment; but the Health Commission still states that there is not an effective anti-viral treatment. US Officials have remarked that, at present, there is currently no vaccine for the virus.
  • China’s Finance Ministry and National Health Commission also offered CNY 60.3bln in an attempt to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

*LUNAR NEW YEAR EXTENSION

  • China has announced that the Lunar New Year holiday will be extended by an additional 3-days. At present, it is unclear if financial markets in the region will re-open on Friday once the original holiday period has concluded or remain closed until Monday in-line with the extension to the holiday period itself.
  • While a significant move by the Chinese Government, designed to stem the spread of the virus during the heighted period of travel, it is a step which has taken place before. In 2003, due to the SARS outbreak, the May market holiday was extended by an additional 4-days.
  • In terms of quarantines, according to the Beijing News, Beijing will not be instigating a lockdown of the city; wearing masks is now mandatory. Additionally, as of today, all tour group businesses are to be suspended in Beijing. CNBC’s Yoon, over the weekend, noted that China has imposed travel restrictions to Beijing – suspending inter-provincial road passenger transport from Sunday.

*MARKET IMPACT

  • Impact in APAC is somewhat clouded by the number of market closures, but the bourses that are open have been under significant pressure due to the virus; Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) for instance.
  • Additionally, a safe-haven bid is present across the JPY, debt complex and spot gold, albeit are all off overnight highs. WTI and Brent front month futures are down in excess of USD 1/bbl thus far as demand related concerns continue to weigh on the complex. Saudi Oil Minister Abdulaziz has downplayed the virus impact, stating that OPEC+ is flexible to respond market needs as is necessary.
  • Luxury and travel names have been most significantly impacted within Europe with the Stoxx 600 travel & leisure sector down in excess of 2% as is the broader consumer discretionary sector. As have energy Co’s, in-line with the complex’s price action.
  • Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam has upgraded their alter level to its highest position and has stated the virus has the potential to extended Hong Kong’s recession throughout 2020. Additionally, a housing estate which the Government commented may be used as a possible quarantine facility if necessary was set on fire by the City’s protestors. Public Sector staff, including medical staff, have threatened to go on strike unless the mainland border is shut.

*CHINA IMPACT

  • The scale on China is, as aforementioned, hard to determine. Government data for the Lunar New Year thus-far provides some indication. Railway Transport on Saturday 25th was -42% YY, passenger flights -42% YY and overall transport -29% YY.
  • As a comparison measure, the 2003 SARS outbreak equated to a 11.1% impact on Q1 growth while Q2 saw a 9.1% impact; however, analysts note that consumption and services which are being severely impacted by the coronavirus are a much more significant contributor to the economy than it was in 2003., FT. With the services sector now equating to 54% of GDP vs. 42% of GDP in 2003 and as such the impact is likely to be more substantial., Danske Bank.
  • Impact may also be exacerbated due to the virus striking in the midst of a prolonged trade war with the US, which has already weakened the Chinese economy.
  • GDP could see a reduction of as much as 1ppt in H1 and may well prompt a number of stimulus measures by the Chinese Government., Danske Bank. Overall, the severity of the virus is difficult to determine with the length at which it remains significant issue for China/world and the driving theme for markets likely to be the main determinants for ramifications both in China and globally.
